III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Policy and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12703
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for the adoption services provided under R 400.12704
to R 400.12713
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency accepted youth under safe delivery act and placed with
adoption supervisor.
Investigation On 4/2/25 Complainant anonymously reported Adoption
Supervisor accepted placement of a child under the Safe
Delivery of Newborns Act. The act required placement by a Child
Placing Agency (CPA). Complainant reported that Adoption
Supervisor was also the daughter of Chief Administrator.
Complainant indicated there may be a violation of adoption
placement services, agency services, and safeguarding privacy.
Complainant did not indicate if Adoption Supervisor had an
approved adoption evaluation.
Interviews
On 4/4/25 Complainant was interviewed by phone. Complainant
stated that Safe Delivery of Newborns Act required the newborn to
be surrendered to an emergency service provider such as a
hospital, police or fire station. The emergency provider would then
send the child to a CPA for placement, and the CPA places the
baby with an approved adoptive parent. Complainant stated they
were aware the agency was a licensed CPA. However, they were
concerned about an infant being placed with staff. Complainant
indicated the court “frowned upon” placements like that.
Complainant reported Adoption Supervisor had an approved
adoption evaluation through a different CPA. However,
complainant was unsure if Keane Center had a policy about
placing with employees or family members, or a policy regarding
placement with the longest waiting applicant. Complainant
questioned if the child’s needs were best served by this
placement. Complainant was also concerned about the agency
safeguarding the rights of the biological mother as the adoptive
mother (Adoption Supervisor) and adoptive grandmother (Chief
Administrator) potentially had access to information about the
biological mother. Complainant clarified they did not have any
2

concerns about Adoption Supervisor, or her suitability as an
adoptive parent. However, from the outside it looked as if there
was preferential treatment of family occurring at this agency.
On 4/8/24 Chief Administrator was interviewed by phone. Chief
Administrator confirmed an infant was placed with Adoption
Supervisor through Safe Delivery of Newborns Act. The agency
did not have a policy regarding placements with staff or relatives,
nor did they have a policy regarding the order of approved
applicants to be considered for placement. Chief Administrator
confirmed Adoption Supervisor had been on the waitlist for a
placement and had an approved Adoption Evaluation through
another CPA. The surrendered newborn fit the placement
specifications of Adoption Supervisor’s evaluation. All fees and
policies applied to Adoption Supervisor just as they would with any
other applicants. Regarding the safeguarding of the biological
mother’s information, Chief Administrator reported the case was
treated as any other case and all laws and policies followed. The
case information was a confidential record, just as any other
adoption. Chief Administrator stated the biological mother’s
information was anonymous, and minimal details were provided
by the hospital when the baby was placed. The information that
was provided was redacted. Chief Administrator noted the Safe
Delivery process is not perfect, as the court had previously shared
information about biological parents in hearing before. However,
Chief Administrator stated she would not share information and
would follow the law.
Documents Reviewed
• Adoption Evaluation of Adoption Supervisor- Completed on
10/29/2024 by a licensed Child Placing Agency. The
evaluation recommended adoptive placement of a child 0-
12 months of age, of any religious background, of
Caucasian, Hispanic, Asian, bi-racial or of any combination
of races including African American. The family was
approved to adopt a child who was generally healthy or
with minor and/or correctable impairments through a
domestic adoption from the United States. They were
approved to adopt a child who was exposed to nicotine or
marijuana, but not a child that was exposed to alcohol
during the pregnancy.
• Program Statement- The program statement did not
address placement with staff or family members. The
document stated, “Each placement will be planned to
assure an emotionally stable and financially secure home
for the child”.
3

Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and documentation
review, it was determined the agency followed their policy and
procedures regarding placement. The agency did not have a
specific policy regarding placement with staff. The placement of
the child followed the approved specifications for the adoptive
home.
CONSULTATION:
The agency was provided consultation that a policy regarding
placement with staff or relatives may be beneficial as it would
provide clarification for the court and other service providers,
should they have questions or concerns regarding rule compliance
of future placements.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
